questionOriginal: My health care provider told me to call the North Dakota Department of Health’s Public Health Hotline about getting tested for coronavirus (COVID-19)?
questionText: My health care provider told me to call the North Dakota Department of Health’s Public Health Hotline about getting tested for coronavirus (COVID-19)?
answerOriginal:
The North Dakota Department of Health has authorized providers to use their judgement on who should be tested for COVID-19. Contact a health care provider; they will determine if you need to be tested for COVID-19.

The North Dakota Department of Health has provided the following guidance to health care providers: Health care providers should not refer patients to the North Dakota Department of Health for medical consultation or screening to determine the need for testing.
answerText: The North Dakota Department of Health has authorized providers to use their judgement on who should be tested for COVID-19. Contact a health care provider; they will determine if you need to be tested for COVID-19. The North Dakota Department of Health has provided the following guidance to health care providers: Health care providers should not refer patients to the North Dakota Department of Health for medical consultation or screening to determine the need for testing.

questionOriginal: What resources are available to assist with housing and living expenses?
questionText: What resources are available to assist with housing and living expenses?
answerOriginal:
• Housing & Homeless Services includes resources provided by state agencies and their private sector partners to help people experiencing a housing crisis.
  • Community Action Agencies have childcare, emergency, food, housing, tax, utility and weatherization assistance programs. Contact the CAA in your area for more information.
  • ND Department of Human Services provides food, cash assistance, childcare and health care coverage. Contact DHS directly for additional information.
  • Great Plains Food Bank supports food pantries and support kitchens statewide. Locations are list by county.  Click here for greatplainsfoodbank.org.
  • First Link 2-1-1 connects anyone for listening options, support and referrals to community resources and crisis intervention. Click here for myfirstlink.org or use your phone to dial 211.
  • Money Follows the Person helps the disabled community navigate health, housing and other services. Information is provided by region. Click here for Money Follows the Person.
  • Salvation Army assists with a wide range of basic needs services including food and clothing. Click here to find your local Salvation Army office.
answerText:
Housing & Homeless Services includes resources provided by state agencies and their private sector partners to help people experiencing a housing crisis.
Community Action Agencies have childcare, emergency, food, housing, tax, utility and weatherization assistance programs. Contact the CAA in your area for more information.
ND Department of Human Services provides food, cash assistance, childcare and health care coverage. Contact DHS directly for additional information.
Great Plains Food Bank supports food pantries and support kitchens statewide. Locations are list by county.  Click here for greatplainsfoodbank.org.
First Link 2-1-1 connects anyone for listening options, support and referrals to community resources and crisis intervention. Click here for myfirstlink.org or use your phone to dial 211.
Money Follows the Person helps the disabled community navigate health, housing and other services. Information is provided by region. Click here for Money Follows the Person.
Salvation Army assists with a wide range of basic needs services including food and clothing. Click here to find your local Salvation Army office.

questionOriginal: Do nonprofits qualify for Paycheck Protection Program (PPP)
questionText: Do nonprofits qualify for Paycheck Protection Program (PPP)
answerOriginal:
A nonprofit organization is eligible for PPP only if it:

  1. was in operation on February 15, 2020,
  2. “(vii) the term ‘nonprofit organization’ means an organization that is described in section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and that is exempt from taxation under section 501(a) of such Code;
  3. IRC section 501(c)(19) veterans organizations (501(c)(19) veterans organizations), and tribal business concerns) on the terms set forth in the CARES Act.
  4. with fewer than 500 employees

Nonprofits businesses who primarily engaged in political or lobbying activities (13 CFR § 120.110 (r)) or derives over 50% of its gross annual revenue from political or lobbying activities are not eligible.
answerText:
A nonprofit organization is eligible for PPP only if it: 
was in operation on February 15, 2020,
“(vii) the term ‘nonprofit organization’ means an organization that is described in section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and that is exempt from taxation under section 501(a) of such Code;
IRC section 501(c)(19) veterans organizations (501(c)(19) veterans organizations), and tribal business concerns) on the terms set forth in the CARES Act.
with fewer than 500 employees
 Nonprofits businesses who primarily engaged in political or lobbying activities (13 CFR § 120.110 (r)) or derives over 50% of its gross annual revenue from political or lobbying activities are not eligible.

questionOriginal: Can nonprofits apply for Emergency Injury Disaster Loans (EIDL)
questionText: Can nonprofits apply for Emergency Injury Disaster Loans (EIDL)
answerOriginal:
A nonprofit organization is eligible for EIDL only if it:

(a) was in operation before January 31, 2020, and

(b) with fewer than 500 employees

Nonprofits businesses who primarily engaged in political or lobbying activities (13 CFR § 120.110 (r)) or derives over 50% of its gross annual revenue from political or lobbying activities are not eligible.

Please note:

The PPP is limited in scope to section 501(c)(3) and section 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, while all non-profit organizations are eligible for emergency EIDL grants.
answerText: A nonprofit organization is eligible for EIDL only if it: (a) was in operation before January 31, 2020, and (b) with fewer than 500 employees Nonprofits businesses who primarily engaged in political or lobbying activities (13 CFR § 120.110 (r)) or derives over 50% of its gross annual revenue from political or lobbying activities are not eligible. Please note: The PPP is limited in scope to section 501(c)(3) and section 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, while all non-profit organizations are eligible for emergency EIDL grants.

questionOriginal: Are personal guarantees required for PPP Loans and EIDL
questionText: Are personal guarantees required  for PPP Loans and EIDL
answerOriginal:
• No collateral or personal guarantee required for PPP loans
  • The EIDL loans waives personal guarantee up to $200,000, and requirement of inability to obtain credit elsewhere.
answerText:
No collateral or personal guarantee required for PPP loans
The EIDL loans waives personal guarantee up to $200,000, and requirement of inability to obtain credit elsewhere.

questionOriginal: Do employees of a nonprofit qualify for unemployment Insurance (UI)
questionText: Do employees of a nonprofit qualify for unemployment Insurance (UI)
answerOriginal:
Most nonprofit organizations do not pay per-worker unemployment taxes and instead have “reimbursable arrangements” with state unemployment programs, which require them to reimburse the state for 100 percent of the cost of unemployment compensation paid to their laid off or furloughed workers. 

The CARES Act - Sec. 2103. Emergency Unemployment Relief for Governmental Entities and Nonprofit Organizations does offer flexibility in paying reimbursement where  provisions would reduce the amount that nonprofits organizations are required to reimburse states for benefits paid to their workers who claim unemployment insurance by 50 percent through December 31, 2020. .  Check with the ND Job Service https://www.jobsnd.com/ and your nonprofit employer to determine if unemployment benefits were paid to the state.
answerText: Most nonprofit organizations do not pay per-worker unemployment taxes and instead have “reimbursable arrangements” with state unemployment programs, which require them to reimburse the state for 100 percent of the cost of unemployment compensation paid to their laid off or furloughed workers.  The CARES Act - Sec. 2103. Emergency Unemployment Relief for Governmental Entities and Nonprofit Organizations does offer flexibility in paying reimbursement where  provisions would reduce the amount that nonprofits organizations are required to reimburse states for benefits paid to their workers who claim unemployment insurance by 50 percent through December 31, 2020. .  Check with the ND Job Service https://www.jobsnd.com/ and your nonprofit employer to determine if unemployment benefits were paid to the state.

questionOriginal: Will employees of nonprofits receive the additional federal unemployment funds?
questionText: Will employees of nonprofits receive the additional federal unemployment funds?
answerOriginal: Workers at nonprofit organizations are also eligible for the Federal Pandemic Unemployment Compensation supplement ($600 a week).
answerText: Workers at nonprofit organizations are also eligible for the Federal Pandemic Unemployment Compensation supplement ($600 a week).

questionOriginal: Do Faith Based organizations qualify for Paycheck Protection Program (PPP)
questionText: Do Faith Based organizations qualify for Paycheck Protection Program (PPP)
answerOriginal:
Yes, faith-based organizations are eligible for PPP if:

  1. was in operation on February 15, 2020,
  2. is either (a) an organization that is exempt from federal income tax under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, and
  3. with fewer than 500 employees
  4. https://www.sba.gov/document/support--faq-regarding-participation-faith-based-organizations-ppp-eidl for more information
answerText:
Yes, faith-based organizations are eligible for PPP if: 
was in operation on February 15, 2020,
is either (a) an organization that is exempt from federal income tax under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, and
with fewer than 500 employees
https://www.sba.gov/document/support--faq-regarding-participation-faith-based-organizations-ppp-eidl for more information

questionOriginal: Can faith-based apply for Emergency Injury Disaster Loans (EIDL)
questionText: Can faith-based apply for Emergency Injury Disaster Loans (EIDL)
answerOriginal:
A faith-based organization is eligible for EIDL only if it:

(a)  was in operation before January 31, 2020, and

(b)   with fewer than 500 employees

(c) https://www.sba.gov/document/support--faq-regarding-participation-faith-based-organizations-ppp-eidl  for additional information
answerText: A faith-based organization is eligible for EIDL only if it: (a)  was in operation before January 31, 2020, and (b)   with fewer than 500 employees (c) https://www.sba.gov/document/support--faq-regarding-participation-faith-based-organizations-ppp-eidl  for additional information

answerOriginal:

  • The EIDL loans waives personal guarantee up to $200,000, and requirement of inability to obtain credit elsewhere.
